title: Authors and Citation
text: Mike Johnson. Author, maintainer. . Funder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Johnson M (2023). FHGestimation: Compute Feature-based Hydrualic Geometries. R package version 0.0.1.
code: @Manual{,   title = {FHGestimation: Compute Feature-based Hydrualic Geometries},   author = {Mike Johnson},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.0.1}, }

title: Compute Feature-based Hydrualic Geometries
text: Using pre-processed observation data USGS, can evaluate learn things estimating power law fits noisy data. Taking random station subset data occurring 2010-01-01 falls within 2 year reoccurance interval (defined via NWM v21 reanalysis product).
code: library(FHGestimation) load("extra/usgs_obs_hydraulics.rda") index = 50    tmp = usgs_obs[[index]] %>%      filter(as.Date(date) > as.Date('2010-01-01')) %>%      filter(inChannel == TRUE) %>%     filter(Ymean > 0) %>%     filter(V > 0) %>%     filter(TW > 0) %>%     filter(Q > 0) %>%     filter(is.finite(Ymean)) %>%    select(date,Q, TW, V, Y = Ymean)  dim(tmp) #> [1] 80  5

title: Compute Feature-based Hydrualic Geometries
text: use FHGestimation package fit Q-Y relationship using OLS NLS models: Overall NLS model provides better fit (albeit small) measured nRMSE pBais.
code: fhg_estimate(Q = tmp$Q, Y = tmp$Y, allowance = .05) #> NLS performs best for the Q-Y realtionship #>   type       exp      coef     nrmse   pb  mean_ape      min_ape  max_ape #> 1    Y 0.4781663 0.2122345 0.1324314 -0.8 0.1410238 0.0084845016 2.227273 #> 2    Y 0.4102660 0.2540058 0.1542132 -2.3 0.1326987 0.0006162981 2.296017 #>   method #> 1    nls #> 2    ols

title: Compute Feature-based Hydrualic Geometries
text: data regarding three hydraulic states (V,TW,Y) can ensure solutions found physically valid (meets continuity constraint Q = Y x V x TW). mode OLS NLS models fit, continuity met, Evolutionary approach implemented. produces three unique fits three variables (27 total combinations). crossed identify best performing relationships meet continuity prescribed allowance: example see NLS able provide better fits OLS neither NLS OLS able provide physically valid solutions (c1, c2, viable). GA approach able provide physically valid solution, error almost 10% higher OLS/NLS methods. However combined approach NLS, OLS, GA fit able provide physically valid result 0.9% error seen best performing NLS method.
code: (x = fhg_estimate(Q = tmp$Q,               V = tmp$V,               TW = tmp$TW,               Y = tmp$Y,               allowance = .05)$output) #> NLS performs best for the Q-Y realtionship #> NLS performs best for the Q-TW realtionship #> NLS performs best for the Q-V realtionship #> NLS meets continuity ...  ðŸ‘ #> OLS meets continuity ...  ðŸ‘ #> The best performing method (nls) is physically valid ... ðŸ˜‚ #>     Y  TW   V viable   Y_error  TW_error   V_error tot_error condition #> 1 nls nls nls   TRUE 0.1324314 0.1228453 0.1710605 0.4263372       nls #> 2 ols nls ols   TRUE 0.1542132 0.1228453 0.1954694 0.4725279     combo #> 3 ols ols ols   TRUE 0.1542132 0.1238710 0.1954694 0.4735535       ols #>           c         f        a         b         k         m        r #> 1 0.2122345 0.4781663 18.37954 0.1746765 0.2682225 0.3370959 2.737440 #> 2 0.2540058 0.4102660 18.37954 0.1746765 0.2074655 0.4250980 2.348719 #> 3 0.2540058 0.4102660 18.73285 0.1638955 0.2074655 0.4250980 2.503217

what: Take home points of this work:
title: Compute Feature-based Hydrualic Geometries
text: NLS better OLS predicting single relationships almost every case become defacto approach. fitting entire system, OLS NLS often provide results physically valid. EA approaches can always find physically valid solution often introduce disproportionate error. Instead, using mishmash NLS, OLS, GA fits (cases non-valid solutions), can find solutions minimal error physical validity. argue approach proper way fit FHG relationships. process formalized FHGestimation R packages.
